segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 42
segments.en: Linked Discourses 42

segments.pli: 1. Gāmaṇivagga
segments.en: 1. Chiefs

segments.pli: 11. Bhadrakasutta
segments.en: 11. With Bhadraka

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā mallesu viharati uruvelakappaṃ nāma mallānaṃ nigamo.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Mallas, near the Mallian town called Uruvelakappa.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhadrako gāmaṇi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho bhadrako gāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Bhadraka the village chief went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

segments.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca desetū”ti.
segments.en: “Please, sir, teach me the origin and cessation of suffering.”

segments.pli: “Ahañce te, gāmaṇi, atītamaddhānaṃ ārabbha dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca deseyyaṃ:
segments.en: “Chief, if I were to teach you about the origin and ending of suffering in the past, saying

segments.pli: ‘evaṃ ahosi atītamaddhānan’ti, tatra te siyā kaṅkhā, siyā vimati.
segments.en: ‘this is how it was in the past,’ you might have doubts or uncertainties about that.

segments.pli: Ahañce te, gāmaṇi, anāgatamaddhānaṃ ārabbha dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca deseyyaṃ:
segments.en: If I were to teach you about the origin and ending of suffering in the future, saying

segments.pli: ‘evaṃ bhavissati anāgatamaddhānan’ti, tatrāpi te siyā kaṅkhā, siyā vimati.
segments.en: ‘this is how it will be in the future,’ you might have doubts or uncertainties about that.

segments.pli: Api cāhaṃ, gāmaṇi, idheva nisinno ettheva te nisinnassa dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca desessāmi.
segments.en: Rather, chief, I will teach you about the origin and ending of suffering as I am sitting right here and you are sitting right there.

segments.pli: Taṃ suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
segments.en: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho bhadrako gāmaṇi bhagavato paccassosi.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” Bhadraka replied.

segments.pli: Bhagavā etadavoca:
segments.en: The Buddha said this:

segments.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, gāmaṇi,
segments.en: “What do you think, chief?

segments.pli: atthi te uruvelakappe manussā yesaṃ te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
segments.en: Are there any people here in Uruvelakappa who, if they were executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, it would cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

segments.pli: “Atthi me, bhante, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṃ me vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.
segments.en: “There are, sir.”

segments.pli: “Atthi pana te, gāmaṇi, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṃ te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
segments.en: “But are there any people here in Uruvelakappa who, if they were executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, it would not cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

segments.pli: “Atthi me, bhante, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṃ me vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.
segments.en: “There are, sir.”

segments.pli: “Ko nu kho, gāmaṇi, hetu, ko paccayo yena te ekaccānaṃ uruvelakappiyānaṃ manussānaṃ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
segments.en: “What’s the cause, chief, what’s the reason why, if this was to happen to some people it could cause you sorrow, while if it happens to others it does not?”

segments.pli: “Yesaṃ me, bhante, uruvelakappiyānaṃ manussānaṃ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā, atthi me tesu chandarāgo.
segments.en: “The people regarding whom this would give rise to sorrow are those I desire and love.

segments.pli: Yesaṃ pana, bhante, uruvelakappiyānaṃ manussānaṃ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā, natthi me tesu chandarāgo”ti.
segments.en: The people regarding whom this would not give rise to sorrow are those I don’t desire and love.”

segments.pli: “Iminā tvaṃ, gāmaṇi, dhammena diṭṭhena viditena akālikena pattena pariyogāḷhena atītānāgate nayaṃ nehi:
segments.en: “With this present phenomenon that is seen, known, immediate, attained, and fathomed, you may infer to the past and future:

segments.pli: ‘yaṃ kho kiñci atītamaddhānaṃ dukkhaṃ uppajjamānaṃ uppajji sabbaṃ taṃ chandamūlakaṃ chandanidānaṃ.
segments.en: ‘All the suffering that arose in the past was rooted and sourced in desire.

segments.pli: Chando hi mūlaṃ dukkhassa.
segments.en: For desire is the root of suffering.

segments.pli: Yampi hi kiñci anāgatamaddhānaṃ dukkhaṃ uppajjamānaṃ uppajjissati, sabbaṃ taṃ chandamūlakaṃ chandanidānaṃ.
segments.en: All the suffering that will arise in the future will be rooted and sourced in desire.

segments.pli: Chando hi mūlaṃ dukkhassā’”ti.
segments.en: For desire is the root of suffering.’”

segments.pli: “Acchariyaṃ, bhante, abbhutaṃ, bhante.
segments.en: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing!

segments.pli: Yāva subhāsitañcidaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā:
segments.en: How well said this was by the Buddha!

segments.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ uppajjamānaṃ uppajjati, sabbaṃ taṃ chandamūlakaṃ chandanidānaṃ.
segments.en: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.

segments.pli: Chando hi mūlaṃ dukkhassā’ti.
segments.en: For desire is the root of suffering.’

segments.pli: Atthi me, bhante, ciravāsī nāma kumāro bahi āvasathe paṭivasati.
segments.en: I have a boy called Ciravāsi, who resides in a house away from here.

segments.pli: So khvāhaṃ, bhante, kālasseva vuṭṭhāya purisaṃ uyyojemi:
segments.en: I rise early and send someone, saying:

segments.pli: ‘gaccha, bhaṇe, ciravāsiṃ kumāraṃ jānāhī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Go, my man, and check on my boy Ciravāsi.’

segments.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhante, so puriso nāgacchati, tassa me hoteva aññathattaṃ:
segments.en: Until they get back I worry:

segments.pli: ‘mā heva ciravāsissa kumārassa kiñci ābādhayitthā’”ti.
segments.en: ‘I hope nothing’s wrong with Ciravāsi!’”

segments.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, gāmaṇi,
segments.en: “What do you think, chief?

segments.pli: ciravāsissa kumārassa vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
segments.en: If Ciravāsi was executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, would it cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

segments.pli: “Ciravāsissa me, bhante, kumārassa vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṃ, kiṃ pana me nuppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.
segments.en: “How could it not, sir?”

segments.pli: “Imināpi kho etaṃ, gāmaṇi, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ:
segments.en: “This too is a way to understand:

segments.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ uppajjamānaṃ uppajjati, sabbaṃ taṃ chandamūlakaṃ chandanidānaṃ.
segments.en: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.

segments.pli: Chando hi mūlaṃ dukkhassā’ti.
segments.en: For desire is the root of suffering.’

segments.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, gāmaṇi,
segments.en: What do you think, chief?

segments.pli: yadā te ciravāsimātā adiṭṭhā ahosi, assutā ahosi, te ciravāsimātuyā chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: Before you’d seen or heard of Ciravāsi’s mother, did you have any desire or love or fondness for her?”

segments.pli: “No hetaṃ, bhante”.
segments.en: “No, sir.”

segments.pli: “Dassanaṃ vā te, gāmaṇi, āgamma savanaṃ vā evaṃ te ahosi:
segments.en: “Then was it because you saw or heard of her that you had

segments.pli: ‘ciravāsimātuyā chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vā’”ti?
segments.en: desire or love or fondness for her?”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”.
segments.en: “Yes, sir.”

segments.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, gāmaṇi,
segments.en: “What do you think, chief?

segments.pli: ciravāsimātuyā te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
segments.en: If Ciravāsi’s mother was executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, would it cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

segments.pli: “Ciravāsimātuyā me, bhante, vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṃ, kiṃ pana me nuppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.
segments.en: “How could it not, sir?”

segments.pli: “Imināpi kho etaṃ, gāmaṇi, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ:
segments.en: “This too is a way to understand:

segments.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ uppajjamānaṃ uppajjati, sabbaṃ taṃ chandamūlakaṃ chandanidānaṃ.
segments.en: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.

segments.pli: Chando hi mūlaṃ dukkhassā’”ti.
segments.en: For desire is the root of suffering.’”

segments.pli: Ekādasamaṃ.

suttaplex.blurb: The chief Bhadraka asks the Buddha about the origin and ending of suffering, and the Buddha points out that a loss among Bhadraka’s own community would cause him suffering, due to his attachment.
